body.p: The purpose of this activity is to give you guided practice in carrying out the ANOVA F-test and to teach you how to obtain the ANOVA F-test's output using statistical software.

section.title: Background: Critical Flicker Frequency (CFF) and Eye Color

body.p: There is various flickering light in our environment; for instance, light from computer screens and fluorescent bulbs. If the frequency of the flicker is below a certain threshold, the flicker can be detected by the eye. Different people have slightly different flicker "threshold" frequencies (known as the critical flicker frequency, or CFF). Knowing the critical threshold frequency below which flicker is detected can be important for product manufacturing as well as tests for ocular disease. Do people with different eye color have different threshold flicker sensitivity? A 1973 study ("The Effect of Iris Color on Critical Flicker Frequency," Journal of General Psychology [1973], 91–95) obtained the following data from a random sample of 19 subjects.

image.alt: A table with two rows, labeled "Eye Color" and "Threshold Frequency (CFF)." Here is the data in the table, organized by row (Eye Color, Threshold Frequency (CFF)): Brown, 26.8 Brown, 27.9 Brown, 23.7 Brown, 25 Brown, 26.3 Brown, 24.8 Brown, 25.7 Brown, 24.5 Green, 26.4 Green, 24.2 Green, 28 Green, 26.9 Green, 29.1 Blue, 25.7 Blue, 27.2 Blue, 29.9 Blue, 28.5 Blue, 29.4 Blue, 28.3

body.p: Do these data suggest that people with different eye color have different threshold sensitivity to flickering light? In other words, do the data suggest that threshold sensitivity to flickering light is related to eye color?
Comment: We recommend that before starting, you create for yourself a figure that summarizes this problem, similar to the figures that we presented for the examples that we used in this part.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the data set preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame flicker. Enter the command flicker to see the data. The two variables in the data frame are color and cff.

Now use R to create side-by-side boxplots of CFF by eye color, and supplement them with the descriptive statistics of CFF by eye color. Use the output to check whether the conditions that allow us to safely use the ANOVA F-test are met.
To do this in R, enter the commands:

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link “Open StatCrunch” at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set select the “My computer” link under Load a data set from box on the left side of the page.
Select the "Browse" or “Choose File” (depending on which browser you're using and select the data set you downloaded
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on “Load File”

alternative.p: Note that the data are given in both “stacked form” and in the “unstacked form”.

Now use StatCrunch to create side-by-side boxplots of CFF by eye color and supplement them with the descriptive statistics of CFF by eye color. Use the output to check whether the conditions that allow us to safely use the ANOVA F-test are met.
StatCrunch Instructions:
BoxPlots

ul.li: Choose: Graphics → Boxplot
Select the column variables (eye colors)
Press: Create Graph

alternative.p: Descriptive Statistics

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Summary Stats → Columns
Select the column variables (eye colors)
Press: Calculate

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: a dialog box will likely appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click "OK."
Note that the data are given in both the "stacked form" (c1-c2) and in the "unstacked form" (c3-c5).

Now use Minitab to create side-by-side boxplots of CFF by eye color, and supplement them with the descriptive statistics of CFF by eye color. Use the output to check whether the conditions that allow us to safely use the ANOVA F-test are met.

Boxplots: Choose Graph → Boxplot. Select "With Groups," and click "OK." Under "Graph variables" enter the response variable and under "Categorical variables..." enter the explanatory variable. (To have the means marked in the boxplots click "Data View" and check "Mean symbol").
Descriptive Statistics: Choose Stat → Basic Statistics → Display Descriptive Statistics. Under "Variables." enter the response, and under "By variable" enter the explanatory. Click "OK."

Comment: Note in the output that Minitab chose "blue" as group 1, "brown" as group 2, and "green" as group 3 (which is not the same as our choice). Minitab orders the groups in alphabetical order of the groups' names, and not by the order that the groups appear in the data. It really does not make a big difference here, but is something you should be aware of.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
Note that the data are given in both the "stacked form" (columns 1 and 2) and in the "unstacked form" (columns 3-5).

Now use Excel to create side-by-side boxplots of CFF by eye color, and supplement them with the descriptive statistics of CFF by eye color. Use the output to check whether the conditions that allow us to safely use the ANOVA F-test are met.
First we need to create a table that will list each statistical measure and the value for each eye color.

ul.li: To create this table, first make the row and column labels: in an empty section of your worksheet, pick a cell and type Statistic. Then move one cell to the right and type Blue. Move one cell to the right and type Brown, and then another cell to the right and type Green. Now, in the cell underneath Statistic, type min. Move down one cell and type Q1, then underneath that Median, then Q3, then Max, then St Dev, and finally, n.

alternative.p: Now for each statistic, we'll enter the formula to calculate that statistic and the range of data that corresponds to each eye color. Here are the formulas you'll need:

Unfortunately, Excel can't create boxplots directly, so we have to create a column graph and alter it so that we get boxplots. We start by using our Descriptive Statistics to create a new table that will be the basis for our column graph:

ul.li: Right below your Descriptive Statistics table, type 25th Percentile. Move down one cell and type 50th Percentile, then underneath that 75th Percentile, then Lower limit, and finally Upper limit.

The 25th Percentile values are the same as those for Q1, so select the values for Q1, right-click and select Copy, and then select the empty cells in the 25th Percentile row and right-click and select Paste Special. In the pop-up window, choose Values and click OK.

The 50th Percentile values are equal to Median - Q1, so enter the necessary formulas to calculate those values from the values in your Descriptive Statistics table. For example, if the value for Blue Median is in cell M4, and the value for Blue Q1 is in cell M3, the correct formula for calculating the 50th Percentile for Blue would be =M4-M3.
The 75th Percentile values are equal to Q3 - Median.
The Lower limit values are equal to Q1 - min.
The Upper limit values are equal to Max - Q3.

alternative.p: Now we can finally create our boxplots:

ul.li: Highlight the values in the 25th Percentile, 50th Percentile, and 75th Percentile rows, and then choose Column in the Charts group on the Insert tab.
In the pull-down menu, choose the second option under 2-D Column (labeled Stacked Column if you hover your mouse over it).

Excel will create a stacked column graph for you. The idea here is that the top two boxes in each column will make up our boxplots. We'll add error bars for the min and Max values, and simply remove the bottom box.

Click on the top box in one of the columns to select it, and then click on the plus (+) symbol to bring up the Chart Elements menu options. Click on the Error Bars box to select it, then select the right arrow symbol to see the error bars menu. Click on More Options to bring up the Format Error Bars menu.
In the pop-up window, choose Vertical Error Bars make sure the direction is set to Both and the End Style is set to Cap. Under Error Amount click Custom and then click the Specify Value button.
In the pop-up window, in the Positive Error Value box, enter the range of values in the Upper limit row in the table we created (or click and drag to select those values). Click OK.
Choose Custom under Error Amount and then click the Specify Value button.
In the pop-up window, in the Positive Error Value box, enter the range of values in the Upper limit row in the table we created (or click and drag to select those values). Click OK.

Now repeat the error bar steps for the bottom box in the columns except choose the Negative Error Value box and enter the range of values in the Lower limit row in the table we created (or click and drag to select those values). Click OK

Right-click on the top box in one of the columns and choose Format Data Series. In the pop-up window, choose the Fill (paint can symbol) on the left, and under the Fill menu specify No fill. Under the Border menu specify Solid Line.
Repeat for the middle box in the columns.
Repeat for the bottom box in the columns, except this time specify No fill and No line. This will cause the bottom box to simply disappear.
Click on the legend and hit the Delete key to remove it.
Click on the horizontal lines in the background of the graph and hit the Delete key to remove them.
Finally, right-click on the y-axis, and choose Format Axis from the pop-up menu. Under Axis Options next to Bounds/Minimum 20 in the text box.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Enter the data for people with blue eyes in L1.
Enter the data for people with brown eyes in L2.
Enter the data for people with green eyes in L3

Now use your TI graphing calculator to create side-by-side boxplots of CFF by eye color, and supplement them with the descriptive statistics of CFF by eye color. Use the output to check whether the conditions that allow us to safely use the ANOVA F-test are met.

ul.li: Either clear any equations you may have in your calculator by choosing Y=/CLEAR, or else toggle them off by choosing Y= and then pressing the left arrow until = is selected and pressing ENTER.
Choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose 4:PlotsOff. Hit ENTER.
You should see:
Again, choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose one of the available plots. For example, choose 1:Plot1…Off.
Turn the plot ON by using arrows to highlight the word ON, then press ENTER.
Choose the Type: The fourth graph is a modified boxplot.

Choose the correct Xlist:
To access one of the built-in lists, such as L1, press 2ND/ 1.
To access a list you named, use the LIST menu. Press 2nd/LIST/NAMES/ to choose the appropriate list.
Leave Freqlist: blank
Use the down arrow to high Calculate and press ENTER.
Choose Freq: 1 (the number one).
Choose the Mark you prefer.
You should see:
To view the boxplot, choose ZOOM/9: ZoomStat.

If you want to change the viewing window, choose WINDOW and set Xmin, Xmax, Xscl (distance between tick marks on x-axis), Ymin, Ymax, Yscl (distance between tick marks on y-scale), Xres (leave Xres at 1).
You can choose TRACE and then use the left/right arrows to display minX, Q1, Med, Q3, maxX.

You can display up to 3 boxplots on one screen by turning on three Stat Plots (one for L1, L2, and L3). . Once you’ve got all the boxplots turned on, you can ZOOM/9:ZoomStat to see all boxplots on the same screen.
If you have side-by-side boxplots displayed, you can choose TRACE, then use the up/down arrows to choose one of the boxplots and the left/right arrows to display minX, Q1, Med, Q3, maxX.

Choose STAT/CALC/1:1-Var Stats. Specify which list the data are in. For example, if the data are in L1, you enter 2ND/1 to choose L1.
Note: If you don’t specify any particular list, the default list is L1.
To access one of the built-in lists, such as L1, press 2ND/1.
To access a list you named, use the LIST menu. Press 2nd/LIST/NAMES/ to choose the appropriate list.
Press ENTER.

The calculator will display:
x ¯
sample mean (this value is also the population mean if the data in L1 are population data)
Σx sum of the x-values
Σx2 sum of the squared x-values
Sx sample standard deviation
σx population standard deviation
n sample size
minX minimum data value
↓Q1 first quartile (the down arrow indicates to use the down arrow to view the remaining statistics)
Med median
Q3 third quartile
maxX maximum data value

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: For the next question, we need to carry out the ANOVA F-test using R. To do this, we use the aov() command. Similar to the lm() command, the aov() command produces more output than we need, so we will save the output to a variable name and then use other commands to extract the information of interest. We choose here a generic name, cff.aov, but any name would work within the code as long as it is used throughout.
Now we can extract the ANOVA table from cff.aov using either summary() or anova(), which both return the same result.

Note: For more advanced analysis of assumptions for ANOVA, we can use functions such as plot(cff.aov,1) for residual plots, plot(cff.aov,2) for normal QQ plots, and residuals(cff.aov) to extract the residuals.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: For the next question you’ll need to carry out the ANOVA F-test using StatCrunch. Here are the instructions:
Choose: Stat → ANOVA → One Way
Depending on the format of the data, select one of the following options:

ul.li: For stacked data: select the compare values in a single column option, and then specify the column containing the samples (Responses In) and the column containing the population identifiers (Factors).
For unstacked data: select the compare selected columns option and then select the columns containing the samples.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: For the next question you'll need to carry out the ANOVA F-test using Minitab. Here are the instructions:
For stacked data: Choose Stats → ANOVA → One-way. Enter the response and explanatory variables, and click "OK."
For unstacked data: Choose Stats → ANOVA → One-way (Unstacked). Enter the columns where the samples are, and click "OK."

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: For the next question you'll need to carry out the ANOVA F-test using Excel. Here are the instructions:

Note:Before you begin check to make sure you have the Excel Data Analysis Toolpack installed. Under the Data tab you should see a Data Analysis option. If you do not follow these steps to install the Data Analysis Toolpack:

ul.li: Step 1: Click the “File” tab and then click “Options.” The Options window will open.
Step 2: Click “Add-Ins.” Add-Ins is listed at the bottom of the left-hand column.
Step 3: Click the “Go” button, next to Manage Excel Add-Ins. Manage Excel Add-Ins is at the very bottom of the pop up window, underneath the list of Add-In options.
Step 4: Check the “Analysis Toolpak” check box.
Step 5: Click “OK.” The Data Analysis Toolpak is now loaded into Excel.
Step 6: Click the “Data” tab and then click “Data Analysis” — located at the far right of the Toolbar in the Analysis group — to access the Toolpak.

alternative.p: You are now ready to conduct the ANOVA F-test using Excel.

ul.li: Choose Data Analysis in Data tab. In the pop-up window, choose Anova: Single Factor and click OK.
In the next window, enter the range of input data, including the column labels, next to Input Range—in this case, the range is C1:E9.
Make sure that Labels in First Row is checked, and click OK.
TI83: Choose STAT/TESTS/F:ANOVA
TI84: Choose STAT/TESTS/H:ANOVA
You should see:
Enter the lists, separated by commas.
To access one of the built-in lists, such as L3, press 2ND/ 3.
NOTE: The comma key is found over the 7 key.
Close with the right parenthesis, then press ENTER.
You should see:
Press ENTER.
